user_request: A Father's Day poem about a dad being a hero and role model.

revision_history.draft:
He peeled the onions while I told him
what happened at school. He didn't ask.
Instead, he made a slotted spoon from a knife
and fished each ring out whole,
careful not to nick them.

The pot on the back burner turned green.
Steam climbed past his ears and he let it.
I watched him press the heel of his hand against his cheek
like that meant something could be pushed back —
the way you push a stovetop burners out of frame
with your body at the kitchen door.

When I said *what now* he didn't flinch.
He poured rice into a bowl, added salt,
cracked an egg over it like someone dividing
a field between heirs. He stirred with a spoon
he found in the drawer labeled *spoons.*
The handle was chipped. He knew this.

He sat across from me at the table
still holding the spoon.
His fingers were stained. I meant that literally.
I had not come home to notice men's hands.
But his were dark with it — something
between violet and a color he must have
mistaken for water, once.

A child's drawing hung above our heads,
pinned there months ago by both of us
not wanting to be the one to take it down.
It showed a dog. A dog doing somersaults.
My son's handwriting below said *Daddy.*
He looked at it the way you look at a fence
you've built twice: once, then again,
then only at the edges of your walking.

I wanted to say something. I opened my mouth
and what came out was almost there —
some version of *You're not alone,* which
isn't true. He already knew that.
He'd known it since the garage door
would would wouldn't and he stood in the rain
with a wrench, with nothing else.

So I ate my饭卡被吃掉了，重试一次。
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The central conceit — a father who is heroic *without* being heroic, who holds together dinner instead of grand gestures — has genuine force. The onion-pressing passage (lines 3–6) is the poem's strongest moment: "he let it" earns its quiet. The egg-cracking simile that divides a field between heirs also works because it's specific and visual; it doesn't just *mean* sacrifice, it *shows* what sacrifice looks like in a kitchen.

The closing image of the child's drawing above the table — almost any poem would collapse under such weight, but here "a dog. A dog doing somersaults" earns its simplicity because the detail is precise and strange enough to hold attention. The son's handwriting "My son's handwriting below said *Daddy.*" lands with real weight partly because it's understated.

The garage door passage (lines 32–34) also works — the ambiguity of "would would wouldn't" enacts the confusion of a person who can no longer parse their own life. That line earns its difficulty.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / earned vs. unearned emotion.** The poem is strongest when it resists telling the reader what to feel (the "You're not alone" moment, lines 31–34). When it *does* explain itself, that's where the emotional weight gets watered down. Direction: cut or radically compress everything from line 25 onward — "I wanted to say something" through the garage door passage. Let the kitchen objects do their own work without editorializing.

**Cliché / near-cliché language.** "Tucked in at night with a kiss and a song," "saving the day," "lead by example" — these are quoted directly but they still need to be named as what they are: dead phrases. The poem's energy comes from *against* cliché, so naming where it leans on them is part of the revision.

**Overextension / structural bloat.** The poem runs 36 lines and says roughly three things — that fathers hold dinner together, that a child drew "Daddy," that he stood in rain with a wrench. Line 25 through line 34 adds nothing to what we already feel from the kitchen scenes. Direction: end at or before line 20, or find one final concrete image after the drawing that doesn't narrate *about* feeling.

**Redundancy / "fingers stained" (lines 19 and 27).** The stain appears twice with different explanations — once literally, once metaphorically. One version is enough. Direction: choose which reading of the stain you want to commit to and cut the other.

**Weak line breaks.** Lines break on syntactic completions almost every time (

revision_history.draft:
He peeled the onions while I told him
what happened at school. He didn't ask.
Instead, he made a slotted spoon from a knife
and fished each ring out whole,
careful not to nick them.

The pot on the back burner turned green.
Steam climbed past his ears and he let it.
I watched him press the heel of his hand against his cheek —
like that meant something could be pushed back —

When I said *what now* he didn't flinch.
He poured rice into a bowl, added salt,
cracked an egg over it like someone dividing
a field between heirs. He stirred with a spoon
he found in the drawer labeled *spoons.*
The handle was chipped. He knew this.

His fingers were dark with it — something
between violet and a color he must have
mistaken for water, once.

A child's drawing hung above our heads,
pinned there months ago by both of us
not wanting to be the one to take it down.
It showed a dog. A dog doing somersaults.
My son's handwriting below said *Daddy.*
He looked at it the way you look at a fence:
built twice, then only at the edges.

I wanted to say something. I opened my mouth
and what came out was almost there —
some version of *You're not alone,* which
isn't true. He already knew that.
He'd known it since the burner turned green,
since he held a whole ring of onion intact.

final_poem:
He peeled the onions while I told him
what happened at school. He didn't ask.
Instead, he made a slotted spoon from a knife
and fished each ring out whole,
careful not to nick them.

The pot on the back burner turned green.
Steam climbed past his ears and he let it.
I watched him press the heel of his hand against his cheek —
like that meant something could be pushed back —

When I said *what now* he didn't flinch.
He poured rice into a bowl, added salt,
cracked an egg over it like someone dividing
a field between heirs. He stirred with a spoon
he found in the drawer labeled *spoons.*
The handle was chipped. He knew this.

His fingers were dark with it — something
between violet and a color he must have
mistaken for water, once.

A child's drawing hung above our heads,
pinned there months ago by both of us
not wanting to be the one to take it down.
It showed a dog. A dog doing somersaults.
My son's handwriting below said *Daddy.*
He looked at it the way you look at a fence:
built twice, then only at the edges.

I wanted to say something. I opened my mouth
and what came out was almost there —
some version of *You're not alone,* which
isn't true. He already knew that.
He'd known it since the burner turned green,
since he held a whole ring of onion intact.
